docs.lead_paragraph: In the initial skirmishes last year over how to allocate potentially huge Federal budget surpluses, President Clinton triumphed politically by casting himself as the prudent protector of Social Security against irresponsible Republican tax cutters. Now Republican leaders have taken a shot at turning that dynamic on its head. Putting aside more than a year of squabbling among themselves, they presented a broad budget outline on Thursday that will almost certainly prove impossible to turn into detailed legislation but that gives the party a unified set of principles with which to face the White House.
docs.abstract: turning the tables**News analysis of Republican attempt to turn tables on Social Security as Democratic by promising to be even purer than Pres Clinton on protecting program; Republican budget plan would end longstanding practice of spending money earmarked for retirement system, and instead set it aside to be used to shore up system or to reduce national debt (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: QUILLAN-Francis Seymour. Retired senior vice president of The Prudential Insurance Company of America died February 27 at his home in Palm City, FL. He was 86. Mr. Quillan was born on Block Island, RI on September 12, 1912. He was the son of Edward Thomas Quillan and the former Mabel Hayes. He graduated from Moses Brown School in 1929. In 1933 he graduated Summa cum Laude in mathematics from Brown University where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and admitted to Sigma Xi, an honorary scientific fraternity. Mr. Quillan joined the Prudential in 1933. In 1961 he was named senior vice president in charge of the General Office Administration, Claim, Debit Policy and Ordinary Policy Departments. In 1969 he also assumed responsibility for the Governmental Health Program Department. Mr. Quillan retired in 1973. For 37 years Mr. Quillan resided in Glen Ridge, NJ and was a member of the Board of Education there from 1951 until 1963. He served as president of the board from 1955 to 1963. Mr. Quillan had been vice president of the Associated Boards of Education of Essex County, treasurer and trustee of the United Community Corporation of Newark, chairman of the board of the Better Business Bureau of Greater Newark, a member of the Education Committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, the national director of the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity, a director of the National Urban League, and the metro director of the National Alliance of Businessmen for Newark. Mr. Quillan was married on October 7, 1939 to the former Frances Lane of Nutley, NJ who died in 1993. He is survived by four children, Marjorie Wendell of Chatham, NJ, Joanne Cotterill of Madison, NJ, Dorothy Williams of Mystic, CT and George Quillan of Morristown, NJ; three grandsons and three granddaughters; a brother, Edward Hayes Quillan of East Greenwich, RI; two nieces and one grandnephew. Services will be private. Those who wish may contribute to Hospice of Martin & St. Lucie, P.O. Box 1168, Stuart, FL 34995-1168.

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge here today ordered the final liquidation of the insolvent HIP Health Plan of New Jersey by March 31 after rejecting a last-ditch effort by the insurer's New York-based parent company to pull it from the brink. ''This is the end of HIP of New Jersey,'' said Robert Conroy, a lawyer who has represented the Medical Society of New Jersey, an association of doctors in the state, throughout the months of uncertainty over HIP's future. ''Come March 31, you can blow taps.''

headline.main: Spurning Rescue Bid, Judge Orders an H.M.O. to Close

docs.abstract: Judge orders final liquidation of insolvent HIP Health Plan of New Jersey by March 31 after rejecting last-ditch effort by insurer's New York-based parent company to pull it from the brink; if ruling stands, it would end nearly a five-month-long drama that plunged HIP's 165,000 patients into confusion and health providers into a frenzy to recoup nearly $120 million they are owed by plan and Pinnacle Health Enterprises, Virginia company that went bankrupt afer ending into medical management contract with HIP promising to make it more competitive (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A Feb. 28 Week in Review article admits that the enrollee appeals data for health maintenance organizations in New York and other states are ''problematic.'' Just how problematic was revealed in my study last November, ''H.M.O.'s vs. Disclosure.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Justice Harry A. Blackmun, a modest Midwestern Republican who became a passionate defender of the right to abortion in 24 years on the Supreme Court, died today at the age of 90. Justice Blackmun, who retired from the Court five years ago, died of complications after hip replacement surgery, the Court announced. He underwent the procedure last week after a fall at his home in suburban Virginia.

headline.main: Justice Blackmun, Author of Abortion Right, Dies

docs.abstract: Justice Harry A Blackmun, modest Midwestern Republican who became passionate defender of right to abortion in 24 years on Supreme Court, dies at age of 90; he had retired from Court five years ago; despite active, 62-year career as lawyer and judge, his name is forever linked to issue of abortion and to opinion that bore his signature, Roe v Wade; he began his tenure on Supreme Court in 1970 as liflong Republican never known for breaking new ground or challenging status quo; by time of his retirement, he was one of last liberal voices on transformed Court; although vote in Roe v Wade was 7 to 2, it was Blackmun who became personal symbol of abortion issue that assumed increasingly dominant, and divisive, role in American politics; although Blackmun maintained that it was Court that changed, not he, evidence of his own evolution is unmistakable; one example is reversal of his long-held support of death penalty, having concluded after many years that capital punishment could not be carried out in manner consistent with Constitution; Harry Andrew Blackmun was born Nov 12, 1908; detailed profile of his life and career; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. Exhibition highlights include the Hall of Biodiversity, which focuses on the variety and interdependence of living things. ''Epidemic! The World of Infectious Disease'' examines how best to control the worldwide spread of infectious disease; through Sept. 6. Tomorrow and Sunday from noon to 6:30 P.M., ''Microbes in the Movies,'' programs exploring the depiction of infectious disease in film as well as the cultural and historical contexts in which these portrayals were created. Examples include public service announcements, documentaries and science fiction. Topics include H.I.V., tuberculosis, ebola, leporsy, living with disabilities, politics and epidemics. Discussions with filmmakers, media critics, health specialists and activists follow the screenings. For a complete program, call (212)769-5200. Tickets: $8; $7 for members, students and the elderly. The series continues through March 25. Also this weekend, ''Women of the World: Diverse Perspectives.'' Tomorrow and Sunday: Anne Makepeace's ''Baby, It's You'' (1998), a video in which the filmmaker talks about the journey she and her husband make to conceive a child; ''Breast Cancer and Women's Health,'' with Michele Brasch, a Wellness Specialist at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center Prevention and Screening Program, gives an overview of breast cancer, focusing on the prevention and early detection through breast self-examination and mammography, at 2 and 3:30 P.M. ''Ladies of Song From the Ellington Legacy,'' a centennial celebration of the birth of Duke Ellington, with a program focusing on the women who contributed to Ellington's success. The singer-composer Lenora Zenzalai Helm pays tribute to the volcalists Ella Fitzgerald, Mahalia Jackson, Ivie Anderson and others. She will perform with the Zenzalai Project, at 2:30 and 4 P.M. Free with museum admission, in the Leonhardt People Center, Charles A. Dana Education Wing, second floor. Information: (212)769-5315. ''Primates: The Jean Baulu Collection of Antique Prints,'' about 50 prints and three books ranging from the 1600's to the present. Closes April 25. Photographs from E.T. Gilliard's 1953-54 expedition to the Middle Sepik River in Papua New Guinea. Closes March 28. The Imax films are ''Africa's Elephant Kingdom'' and ''Amazon.'' Through June. In the Imax Theater on Friday and Saturday nights at 9, ''U2 in 3-D,'' and at 10, ''Pink Floyd's 'Dark Side of the Moon' in 3-D.'' Tickets: $9. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; suggested admission: $8; students and the elderly, $6; children 12 and under, $4.50; under 2, free. A combination ticket including museum admission and one film or any special exhibition; $13; students and the elderly, $9; children 12 and under , $7; under 2, free. Information: (212)769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212)769-5200.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Not mentioned in ''Managed Care's Other Problem: It's Not What You Think'' (Week in Review, Feb. 28) is the fact that although hospitals do not admit or discharge patients (only the doctor or the patient himself can do this), insurance companies routinely deny hospitals payment for the last few days of a patient's stay while continuing to pay the patient's doctor. Even more insidious is insurance companies' lowering of the level of care during the course of a patient's stay, with a corresponding lowering of the reimbursement.
docs.abstract: Letter by hospital officer Jeffrey Newman says Feb 28 article on managed care does not mention fact that insurance companies routinely deny hospitals payment for last few days of patient's stay while continuing to pay patient's doctor

docs.lead_paragraph: When an 86-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease broke her hip, Deborah Newquist was the person who stayed with her at the hospital here. Years earlier, Dr. Newquist had arranged 24-hour home care for the woman and her bedridden husband, and she also took care of everything from having their house painted to getting their cat to the veterinarian. When the husband died in November, it seemed fitting that Dr. Newquist was among the six mourners at his funeral. After eight years on the job for the couple, she had become a professional member of the family.

headline.main: The Growing Business of Helping Elders Cope

docs.abstract: Deborah Newquist is geriatric care manager in Newport Beach, Calif, occupation that did not exist when she received her master's degree in social work 24 years ago; field was born in response to nation's rapidly aging population and health care system's complexity; geriatric care managers, at $70 to $150 hour, generally do not offer hands-on care; part counselors and part social workers, they help manage health care, living arrangements and other affairs of their elderly clients; in doing so, they perform role once filled by families; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Students with disabilities who require special care during the school day are entitled to that care at public expense, the Supreme Court ruled today, as long as the services can be provided by someone other than a doctor. The 7-to-2 decision upheld lower court rulings that required an Iowa school district to provide a trained aide to monitor the needs of a quadriplegic boy who was dependent on a ventilator.

headline.main: Court Says Schools Must Pay For Needs of Disabled Pupils

docs.abstract: Supreme Court rules, 7-2, that students with disabilities who require special care during school day are entitled to that care at public expense, as long as services can be provided by someone other than doctor; decision upholds lower court rulings that require Iowa school district to provide trained aide to monitor needs of Garret Frey, quadriplegic boy who is dependent on ventilator; Justice John Paul Stevens, in majority opinion, disputes contention of Cedar Rapids school district that it would cost over $20,000 a year to care for Frey; Court, in second decision, rules 7 to 2 that private insurance companies that administer part of state's workers' compensation program do not thereby become agents of state for constitutional purposes; decision overturns US appeals court ruling in Philadelphia; Frey photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Richard R. Shinn, a retired chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, who was active in the arts and civic affairs and helped stave off New York City's fiscal crisis in the 1970's, died Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn., after a long battle with leukemia. He was 81. After graduating from Rider College in Trenton, Mr. Shinn began his career at Metropolitan Life in 1939 in the mailroom. He was paid $15 a week.

headline.main: Richard R. Shinn, Retired Metropolitan Life Chief, Dies at 81
